Key Arguments: The legislation represents extreme government censorship and is totalitarian in nature.
It is reminiscent of George Orwell's 'Ministry of Truth' and is contrary to the principles of free speech in a democracy.
The definitions of 'harm' in the legislation are vague and can be manipulated to suppress dissent and political opposition.
The ACMA, being unelected, could be influenced by government direction, leading to potential abuse of power.
The legislation could stifle political communication and debate, impacting democratic processes.
Main Themes: Threats to free speech and democracy
Potential for abuse of power by unelected bodies
Comparison to totalitarian regimes and Orwellian concepts
Notable Quotes: It is government censorship on an extreme level.
It is ‘Orwellian’, in that it seeks to create what George Orwell described as ‘The Ministry of Truth’.
The ACMA is not at arm’s length from government, therefore is fully bound by Ministerial and government dictates.
I contend that any politician or party which attempts to enact this or similar legislation will place itself in very real jeopardy of removal at the next election.
